A General Theory for Client Sampling in Federated Learning

Yann Fraboni1,2 ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Richard Vidal2 ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Laetitia Kameni2&Marco Lorenzi1 1Universit√© C√¥te d‚ÄôAzur, Inria Sophia Antipolis, Epione Research Group, France
2Accenture Labs, Sophia Antipolis, France
Accepted to the International Workshop on Trustworthy Federated Learning in Conjunction with IJCAI 2022.
Abstract

While client sampling is a central operation of current state-of-the-art federated learning (FL) approaches, the impact of this procedure on the convergence and speed of FL remains under-investigated. In this work, we provide a general theoretical framework to quantify the impact of a client sampling scheme and of the clients heterogeneity on the federated optimization. First, we provide a unified theoretical ground for previously reported sampling schemes experimental results on the relationship between FL convergence and the variance of the aggregation weights. Second, we prove for the first time that the quality of FL convergence is also impacted by the resulting covariance between aggregation weights. Our theory is general, and is here applied to Multinomial Distribution (MD) and Uniform sampling, two default unbiased client sampling schemes of FL, and demonstrated through a series of experiments in non-iid and unbalanced scenarios. Our results suggest that MD sampling should be used as default sampling scheme, due to the resilience to the changes in data ratio during the learning process, while Uniform sampling is superior only in the special case when clients have the same amount of data.

1 Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) has gained popularity in the last years as it enables different clients to jointly learn a global model without sharing their respective data. Among the different FL approaches, federated averaging (FedAvg) has emerged as the most popular optimization scheme (McMahan et al., 2017). An optimization round of FedAvg requires data owners, also called clients, to receive from the server the current global model which they update on a fixed amount of Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) steps before sending it back to the server. The new global model is then created as the weighted average of the client updates, according to their data ratio. FL specializes the classical problem of distributed learning (DL), to account for the private nature of clients information (i.e. data and surrogate features), and for the potential data and hardware heterogeneity across clients, which is generally unknown to the server.

In FL optimization, FedAvg was first proven to converge experimentally (McMahan et al., 2017), before theoretical guarantees were provided for any non-iid federated dataset (Wang et al., 2020a; Karimireddy et al., 2020; Haddadpour and Mahdavi, 2019; Khaled et al., 2020). A drawback of naive implementations of FedAvg consists in requiring the participation of all the clients to every optimization round. As a consequence, the efficiency of the optimization is limited by the communication speed of the slowest client, as well as by the server communication capabilities. To mitigate this issue, the original FedAvg algorithm already contemplated the possibility of considering a random subset of mùëöm clients at each FL round. It has been subsequently shown that, to ensure the convergence of FL to its optimum, clients must be sampled such that in expectation the resulting global model is identical to the one obtained when considering all the clients (Wang et al., 2020a; Cho et al., 2020). Clients sampling schemes compliant with this requirement are thus called unbiased. Due to its simplicity and flexibility, the current default unbiased sampling scheme consists in sampling mùëöm clients according to a Multinomial Distribution (MD), where the sampling probability depends on the respective data ratio (Li et al., 2020a; Wang et al., 2020a; Li et al., 2020c; Haddadpour and Mahdavi, 2019; Li et al., 2020b; Wang and Joshi, 2018; Fraboni et al., 2021). Nevertheless, when clients have identical amount of data, clients can also be sampled uniformly without replacement (Li et al., 2020c; Karimireddy et al., 2020; Reddi et al., 2021; Rizk et al., 2020). In this case, Uniform sampling has been experimentally shown to yield better results than MD sampling (Li et al., 2020c).

Previous works proposed unbiased sampling strategies alternative to MD and Uniform sampling with the aim of improving FL convergence. In Fraboni et al. (2021), MD sampling was extended to account for clusters of clients with similar data characteristics, while in Chen et al. (2020), clients sampling probabilities are defined depending on the Euclidean norm of the clients local work. While these works are based on the definition and analysis of specific sampling procedures, aimed at satisfying a given FL criterion, there is currently a need for a general theoretical framework to elucidate the impact of client sampling on FL convergence.

The main contribution of this work consists in deriving a general theoretical framework for FL optimization allowing to clearly quantify the impact of client sampling on the global model update at any FL round. This contribution has important theoretical and practical implications. First, we demonstrate the dependence of FL convergence on the variance of the aggregation weights. Second, we prove for the first time that the convergence speed is also impacted through sampling by the resulting covariance between aggregation weights. From a practical point of view, we establish both theoretically and experimentally that client sampling schemes based on aggregation weights with sum different than 1 are less efficient. We also prove that MD sampling is outperformed by Uniform sampling only when clients have identical data ratio. Finally, we show that the comparison between different client sampling schemes is appropriate only when considering a small number of clients. Our theory ultimately shows that MD sampling should be used as default sampling scheme, due to the favorable statistical properties and to the resilience to FL applications with varying data ratio and heterogeneity.

Our work is structured as follows. In Section 2, we provide formal definitions for FL, unbiased client sampling, and for the server aggregation scheme. In Section 3, we introduce our convergence guarantees (Theorem 1) relating the convergence of FL to the aggregation weight variance of the client sampling scheme. Consistently with our theory, in Section 4, we experimentally demonstrate the importance of the clients aggregation weights variance and covariance on the convergence speed, and conclude by recommending Uniform sampling for FL applications with identical client ratio, and MD sampling otherwise.

2 Background

Before investigating in Section 3 the impact of client sampling on FL convergence, we recapitulate in Section 2 the current theory behind FL aggregation schemes for clients local updates. We then introduce a formalization for unbiased client sampling.

In this setting, to estimate a global model across clients, FedAvg (McMahan et al., 2017) is an iterative training strategy based on the aggregation of local model parameters. At each iteration step tùë°t, the server sends the current global model parameters Œ∏tsuperscriptùúÉùë°\theta^{t} to the clients. Each client updates the respective model by minimizing the local cost function ‚Ñíi‚Äã(Œ∏)subscript‚ÑíùëñùúÉ\mathcal{L}_{i}(\theta) through a fixed amount KùêæK of SGD steps initialized with Œ∏tsuperscriptùúÉùë°\theta^{t}. Subsequently each client returns the updated local parameters Œ∏it+1superscriptsubscriptùúÉùëñùë°1{\theta}_{i}^{t+1} to the server. The global model parameters Œ∏t+1superscriptùúÉùë°1\theta^{t+1} at the iteration step t+1ùë°1t+1 are then estimated as a weighted average:

Œ∏t+1=‚àëi=1npi‚ÄãŒ∏it+1.superscriptùúÉùë°1superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëùùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùúÉùëñùë°1\theta^{t+1}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}{\theta}_{i}^{t+1}. (2)

To alleviate the clients workload and reduce the amount of overall communications, the server often considers m‚â§nùëöùëõm\leq n clients at every iteration. In heterogeneous datasets containing many workers, the percentage of sampled clients m/nùëöùëõm/n can be small, and thus induce important variability in the new global model, as each FL optimization step necessarily leads to an improvement on the mùëöm sampled clients to the detriment of the non-sampled ones. To solve this issue, Reddi et al. (2021); Karimireddy et al. (2020); Wang et al. (2020b) propose considering an additional learning rate Œ∑gsubscriptùúÇùëî\eta_{g} to better account for the clients update at a given iteration. The server aggregation scheme can be written as:

(3)

2.2 Unbiased data agnostic client samplings

While FedAvg was originally based on the uniform sampling of clients (McMahan et al., 2017), this scheme has been proven to be biased and converge to a suboptimal minima of problem (1) (Wang et al., 2020a; Cho et al., 2020; Li et al., 2020c). This was the motivation for Li et al. (2020c) to introduce the notion of unbiasedness, where clients are considered in expectation subject to their importance pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i}, according to Definition 1 below. Unbiased sampling guarantees the optimization of the original FL cost function, while minimizing the number of active clients per FL round. We note that unbiased sampling is not necessarily related to the clients distribution, as this would require to know beforehand the specificity of the clients‚Äô datasets.

Unbiased sampling methods (Li et al., 2020a, c; Fraboni et al., 2021) are currently among the standard approaches to FL, as opposed to biased approaches, known to over- or under-represent clients and lead to suboptimal convergence properties (McMahan et al., 2017; Nishio and Yonetani, 2019; Jeon et al., 2020; Cho et al., 2020), or to methods requiring additional computation work from clients (Chen et al., 2020).

Definition 1 (Unbiased Sampling).

A client sampling scheme is said unbiased if the expected value of the client aggregation is equal to the global deterministic aggregation obtained when considering all the clients, i.e.

ùîºSt‚Å°[‚àëi=1nwi‚Äã(St)‚ÄãŒ∏it]‚âî‚àëi=1npi‚ÄãŒ∏it,‚âîsubscriptùîºsubscriptùëÜùë°superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùë§ùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°superscriptsubscriptùúÉùëñùë°superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëùùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùúÉùëñùë°\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}_{S_{t}}\left[\sum_{i=1}^{n}w_{i}(S_{t})\theta_{i}^{t}\right]\coloneqq\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}\theta_{i}^{t}, (4)

where wj‚Äã(St)subscriptùë§ùëósubscriptùëÜùë°w_{j}(S_{t}) is the aggregation weight of client jùëój for subset of clients StsubscriptùëÜùë°S_{t}.

The sampling distribution uniquely defines the statistical properties of stochastic weights. In this setting, unbiased sampling guarantees the equivalence between deterministic and stochastic weights in expectation. Unbiased schemes of primary importance in FL are MD and Uniform sampling, for which we can derive a close form formula for the aggregation weights :

This condition is satisfied for example by MD sampling and Uniform sampling for identical clients importance.

We finally note that the covariance of the aggregation weights for both MD and Uniform sampling satisfies Assumption 1.

Assumption 1 (Client Sampling Covariance).

There exists a constant Œ±ùõº\alpha such that the client sampling covariance satisfies ‚àÄi‚â†j,Cov‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St),œâj‚Äã(St)]=‚àíŒ±‚Äãpi‚Äãpjformulae-sequencefor-allùëñùëóCovsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùúîùëósubscriptùëÜùë°ùõºsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëó\forall i\neq j,\ \operatorname{Cov}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t}),\omega_{j}(S_{t})\right]=-\alpha p_{i}p_{j}.

We provide in Table 1 the derivation of Œ±ùõº\alpha and the resulting covariance for these two schemes with calculus detailed in Appendix A. Furthermore, this property is common to a variety of sampling schemes, for example based on Binomial or Poisson Binomial distributions (detailed derivations can be found in Appendix A). Following this consideration, in addition to Definition 1, in the rest of this work we assume the additional requirement for a client sampling scheme to satisfy Assumption 1.

2.3 Advanced client sampling techniques

Importance sampling for centralized SGD Zhao and Zhang (2015); Csiba and Richt√°rik (2018) has been developed to reduce the variance of the gradient estimator in the centralized setting and provide faster convergence. According to this framework, each data point is sampled according to a probability based on a parameter of its loss function (e.g. its Lipschitz constant), in opposition to classical sampling where clients are sampled with same probability. These works cannot be seamlessly applied in FL, since in general no information on the clients loss function should be disclosed to the server. Therefore, the operation of client sampling in FL cannot be seen as an extension of importance sampling. Regarding advanced FL client sampling, Fraboni et al. (2021) extended MD sampling to account for collections of sampling distributions with varying client sampling probability. From a theoretical perspective, this approach was proven to have identical convergence guarantees of MD sampling, with albeit experimental improvement justified by lower variance of the clients‚Äô aggregation weights. In Chen et al. (2020), clients probability are set based on the euclidean norm of the clients local work. We show in Appendix A that these advanced client sampling strategies also satisfy our covariance assumption 1, and are thus encompassed by the general theory developed in Section 3.

3 Convergence Guarantees

Based on the assumptions introduced in Section 2, in what follows we elaborate a new theory relating the convergence of FL to the statistical properties of client sampling schemes. In particular, Theorem 1 quantifies the asymptotic relationship between client sampling and FL convergence.

3.1 Asymptotic FL convergence with respect to client sampling

To prove FL convergence with client sampling, our work relies on the following three assumptions (Wang et al., 2020a; Li et al., 2020a; Karimireddy et al., 2020; Haddadpour and Mahdavi, 2019; Wang et al., 2019a, b):

Assumption 2 (Smoothness).

The clients local objective function is LùêøL-Lipschitz smooth, that is, ‚àÄi‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,n},‚à•‚àá‚Ñíi‚Äã(x)‚àí‚àá‚Ñíi‚Äã(y)‚à•‚â§L‚Äã‚à•x‚àíy‚à•formulae-sequencefor-allùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëõdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àásubscript‚Ñíùëñùë•‚àásubscript‚Ñíùëñùë¶ùêødelimited-‚à•‚à•ùë•ùë¶\forall i\in\{1,...,n\},\ \left\lVert\nabla\mathcal{L}_{i}(x)-\nabla\mathcal{L}_{i}(y)\right\rVert\leq L\left\lVert x-y\right\rVert.

Assumption 3 (Bounded Dissimilarity ).

There exist constants Œ≤2‚â•1superscriptùõΩ21\beta^{2}\geq 1 and Œ∫2‚â•0superscriptùúÖ20\kappa^{2}\geq 0 such that for every combination of positive weights {wi}subscriptùë§ùëñ\{w_{i}\} such that ‚àëi=1nwi=1superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùë§ùëñ1\sum_{i=1}^{n}w_{i}=1, we have ‚àëi=1nwi‚Äã‚à•‚àá‚Ñíi‚Äã(x)‚à•2‚â§Œ≤2‚Äã‚à•‚àá‚Ñí‚Äã(x)‚à•2+Œ∫2superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùë§ùëñsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àásubscript‚Ñíùëñùë•2superscriptùõΩ2superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àá‚Ñíùë•2superscriptùúÖ2\sum_{i=1}^{n}w_{i}\left\lVert\nabla\mathcal{L}_{i}(x)\right\rVert^{2}\leq\beta^{2}\left\lVert\nabla\mathcal{L}(x)\right\rVert^{2}+\kappa^{2}. If all the local loss functions are identical, then we have Œ≤2=1superscriptùõΩ21\beta^{2}=1 and Œ∫2=0superscriptùúÖ20\kappa^{2}=0.

Assumption 4 (Unbiased Gradient and Bounded Variance).

We formalize in the following theorem the relationship between the statistical properties of the client sampling scheme and the asymptotic convergence of FL (proof in Appendix B).

Theorem 1 (FL convergence).

Let us consider a client sampling scheme satisfying Definition 1 and Assumption 1. Under Assumptions 2, 3, and 4, and with sufficiently small local step size Œ∑lsubscriptùúÇùëô\eta_{l}, the following convergence bound holds:

1T‚Äã‚àët=0T‚àí1ùîº‚Å°[‚à•‚àá‚Ñí‚Äã(ùúΩt)‚à•2]‚â§ùí™‚Äã(1Œ∑~‚ÄãK‚ÄãT)1ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùë°0ùëá1ùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àá‚ÑísuperscriptùúΩùë°2ùí™1~ùúÇùêæùëá\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left[\left\lVert\nabla{\mathcal{L}}({\bm{\theta}}^{t})\right\rVert^{2}\right]\leq\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\tilde{\eta}KT}\right)
+ùí™‚Äã(Œ∑l2‚Äã(K‚àí1)‚ÄãœÉ2)+ùí™‚Äã(Œ∑~‚Äã[Œ£+‚àëi=1npi2]‚ÄãœÉ2)ùí™superscriptsubscriptùúÇùëô2ùêæ1superscriptùúé2ùí™~ùúÇdelimited-[]Œ£superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ2superscriptùúé2\displaystyle+\mathcal{O}\left(\eta_{l}^{2}(K-1)\sigma^{2}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\tilde{\eta}\left[\Sigma+\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}\right]\sigma^{2}\right) (7)
+ùí™‚Äã(Œ∑l2‚ÄãK‚Äã(K‚àí1)‚ÄãŒ∫2)+ùí™‚Äã(Œ∑~‚ÄãŒ≥‚Äã[(K‚àí1)‚ÄãœÉ2+K‚ÄãŒ∫2]),ùí™superscriptsubscriptùúÇùëô2ùêæùêæ1superscriptùúÖ2ùí™~ùúÇùõædelimited-[]ùêæ1superscriptùúé2ùêæsuperscriptùúÖ2\displaystyle+\mathcal{O}\left(\eta_{l}^{2}K(K-1)\kappa^{2}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\tilde{\eta}\gamma\left[(K-1)\sigma^{2}+K\kappa^{2}\right]\right),

where Œ∑~=Œ∑g‚ÄãŒ∑l~ùúÇsubscriptùúÇùëîsubscriptùúÇùëô\tilde{\eta}=\eta_{g}\eta_{l}, KùêæK is the number of local SGD,

Œ£=‚àëi=1nVar‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St)]Œ£superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõVarsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°\Sigma=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\operatorname{Var}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t})\right] (8)

and

Œ≥=‚àëi=1nVar‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St)]+Œ±‚Äã‚àëi=1npi2.ùõæsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõVarsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°ùõºsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ2\gamma=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\operatorname{Var}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t})\right]+\alpha\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}. (9)

We first observe that any client sampling scheme satisfying the assumptions of Theorem 1 converges to its optimum. Through Œ£Œ£\Sigma and Œ≥ùõæ\gamma, equation (7) shows that our bound is proportional to the clients aggregation weights through the quantities Var‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St)]VarsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°\operatorname{Var}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t})\right] and Œ±ùõº\alpha, which thus should be minimized. These terms are non-negative and are minimized and equal to zero only with full participation of the clients to every optimization round. Theorem 1 does not require the sum of the weights œâi‚Äã(St)subscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°\omega_{i}(S_{t}) to be equal to 1. Yet, for client sampling satisfying Var‚Å°[‚àëi=1nœâi‚Äã(St)]=0Varsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°0\operatorname{Var}\left[\sum_{i=1}^{n}\omega_{i}(S_{t})\right]=0, we get Œ±‚àùŒ£proportional-toùõºŒ£\alpha\propto\Sigma. Hence, choosing an optimal client sampling scheme amounts at choosing the client sampling with the smallest Œ£Œ£\Sigma. This aspect has been already suggested in Fraboni et al. (2021).

The convergence guarantee proposed in Theorem 1 extends the work of Wang et al. (2020a) where, in addition of considering FedAvg with clients performing KùêæK vanilla SGD, we include a server learning rate Œ∑gsubscriptùúÇùëî\eta_{g} and integrate client sampling (equation (3)). With full client participation (Œ£=Œ≥=0Œ£ùõæ0\Sigma=\gamma=0) and Œ∑g=1subscriptùúÇùëî1\eta_{g}=1, we retrieve the convergence guarantees of Wang et al. (2020a). Furthermore, our theoretical framework can be applied to any client sampling satisfying the conditions of Theorem 1. In turn, Theorem 1 holds for full client participation, MD sampling, Uniform sampling, as well as for the other client sampling schemes detailed in Appendix A. Finally, the proof of Theorem 1 is general enough to account for FL regularization methods (Li et al., 2020a, 2019; Acar et al., 2021), other SGD solvers (Kingma and Ba, 2015; Ward et al., 2019; Li and Orabona, 2019), and/or gradient compression/quantization (Reisizadeh et al., 2020; Basu et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2018). For all these applications, the conclusions drawn for client samplings satisfying the assumptions of Theorem 1 still hold.

3.2 Application to current client sampling schemes

MD sampling. When using Table 1 to compute Œ£Œ£\Sigma and Œ≥ùõæ\gamma close-form we obtain:

Œ£M‚ÄãD=1m‚Äã[1‚àí‚àëi=1npi2]‚Äã¬†and¬†‚ÄãŒ≥M‚ÄãD=1m,subscriptŒ£ùëÄùê∑1ùëödelimited-[]1superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ2¬†and¬†subscriptùõæùëÄùê∑1ùëö\Sigma_{MD}=\frac{1}{m}\left[1-\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}\right]\text{ and }\gamma_{MD}=\frac{1}{m}, (10)

where we notice that Œ£M‚ÄãD‚â§1m=Œ≥M‚ÄãDsubscriptŒ£ùëÄùê∑1ùëösubscriptùõæùëÄùê∑\Sigma_{MD}\leq\frac{1}{m}=\gamma_{MD}. Therefore, one can obtain looser convergence guarantees than the ones of Theorem 1, independently from the amount of participating clients nùëõn and set of clients importance {pi}subscriptùëùùëñ\{p_{i}\}, while being inversely proportional to the amount of sampled clients mùëöm. The resulting bound shows that FL with MD sampling converges to its optimum for any FL application.

Uniform sampling. Contrarily to MD sampling, the stochastic aggregation weights of Uniform sampling do not sum to 1. As a result, we can provide FL scenarios diverging when coupled with Uniform sampling. Indeed, using Table 1 to compute Œ£Œ£\Sigma and Œ≥ùõæ\gamma close-form we obtain

Œ£U=[nm‚àí1]‚Äã‚àëi=1npi2,subscriptŒ£ùëàdelimited-[]ùëõùëö1superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ2\Sigma_{U}=\left[\frac{n}{m}-1\right]\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}, (11)

and

Œ≥U=[1+1n‚àí1]‚Äã[nm‚àí1]‚Äã‚àëi=1npi2,subscriptùõæùëàdelimited-[]11ùëõ1delimited-[]ùëõùëö1superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ2\gamma_{U}=\left[1+\frac{1}{n-1}\right]\left[\frac{n}{m}-1\right]\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}, (12)

where we notice that Œ≥U=[1+1n‚àí1]‚ÄãŒ£Usubscriptùõæùëàdelimited-[]11ùëõ1subscriptŒ£ùëà\gamma_{U}=\left[1+\frac{1}{n-1}\right]\Sigma_{U}. Considering that ‚àëi=1npi2‚â§1superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ21\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}\leq 1, we have Œ£U‚â§nm‚àí1subscriptŒ£ùëàùëõùëö1\Sigma_{U}\leq\frac{n}{m}-1, which goes to infinity for large cohorts of clients and thus prevents FL with Uniform sampling to converge to its optimum. Indeed, the condition ‚àëi=1npi2‚â§1superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ21\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}\leq 1 accounts for every possible scenario of client importance {pi}subscriptùëùùëñ\{p_{i}\}, including the very heterogeneous ones. In the special case where pi=1/nsubscriptùëùùëñ1ùëõp_{i}=1/n, we have ‚àëi=1npi2=1/nsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ21ùëõ\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}=1/n, such that Œ£UsubscriptŒ£ùëà\Sigma_{U} is inversely proportional to both nùëõn and mùëöm. Such FL applications converge to the optimum of equation (1) for any configuration of nùëõn, {pi}subscriptùëùùëñ\{p_{i}\} and mùëöm.

Moreover, the comparison between the quantities Œ£Œ£\Sigma and Œ≥ùõæ\gamma for MD and Uniform sampling shows that Uniform sampling outperforms MD sampling when pi=1/nsubscriptùëùùëñ1ùëõp_{i}=1/n. More generally, Corollary 1 provides sufficient conditions with Theorem 1 for Uniform sampling to have better convergence guarantees than MD sampling (proof in Appendix B.7).

Corollary 1.

Uniform sampling has better convergence guarantees than MD sampling when Œ£U‚â§Œ£M‚ÄãDsubscriptŒ£ùëàsubscriptŒ£ùëÄùê∑\Sigma_{U}\leq\Sigma_{MD}, and Œ≥U‚â§Œ≥M‚ÄãDsubscriptùõæùëàsubscriptùõæùëÄùê∑\gamma_{U}\leq\gamma_{MD} which is equivalent to

‚àëi=1npi2‚â§1n‚àím+1.superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ21ùëõùëö1\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}\leq\frac{1}{n-m+1}. (13)

Corollary 1 can be related to Var‚Å°[‚àëi=1nœâi‚Äã(St)]Varsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°\operatorname{Var}\left[\sum_{i=1}^{n}\omega_{i}(S_{t})\right], the variance for the sum of the aggregation weights, which is always null for MD sampling, and different of 0 for Uniform sampling except when pi=1/nsubscriptùëùùëñ1ùëõp_{i}=1/n for all the clients.

A last point of interest for the comparison between MD and Uniform sampling concerns the respective time complexity for selecting clients. Sampling with a Multinomial Distribution has time complexity ùí™‚Äã(n+m‚Äãlog‚Å°(n))ùí™ùëõùëöùëõ\mathcal{O}(n+m\log(n)), where ùí™‚Äã(n)ùí™ùëõ\mathcal{O}(n) comes from building the probability density function to sample clients indices (Tang, 2019). This makes MD sampling difficult to compute or even intractable for large cohorts of clients. On the contrary sampling mùëöm elements without replacement from nùëõn states is a reservoir sampling problem and takes time complexity ùí™(m(1+log(n/m))\mathcal{O}(m(1+\log(n/m))(Li, 1994). In practice, clients either receive identical importance (pi=1/nsubscriptùëùùëñ1ùëõp_{i}=1/n) or an importance proportional to their data ratio, for which we may assume computation pi=ùí™‚Äã(1/n)subscriptùëùùëñùí™1ùëõp_{i}=\mathcal{O}(1/n). As a result, for important amount nùëõn of participating clients, Uniform sampling should be used as the default client sampling due to its lower time complexity. However, for small amount of clients and heterogeneous client importance, MD sampling should be used by default.

Due to space constraints, we only consider in this manuscript applying Theorem 1 to Uniform and MD sampling, which can also be applied to Binomial and Poisson Binomial sampling introduced in Section A, and satisfying our covariance assumption. To the best of our knowledge, we could only find Clustered sampling introduced in Fraboni et al. (2021) not satisfying this assumption. Still, with minor changes, we provide for this sampling scheme a similar bound to the one of Theorem 1 (Appendix B.6), ultimately proving that clustered sampling improves MD sampling.

4 Experiments on real data

In this section, we provide an experimental demonstration of the convergence properties identified in Theorem 1. 111Code and data are available at https://github.com/Accenture/Labs-Federated-Learning/tree/impact_client_sampling. We study a LSTM model for next character prediction on the dataset of The complete Works of William Shakespeare (McMahan et al., 2017; Caldas et al., 2018). We use a two-layer LSTM classifier containing 100 hidden units with an 8 dimensional embedding layer. The model takes as an input a sequence of 80 characters, embeds each of the characters into a learned 8-dimensional space and outputs one character per training sample after 2 LSTM layers and a fully connected one.

When selected, a client performs K=50ùêæ50K=50 SGD steps on batches of size B=64ùêµ64B=64 with local learning rate Œ∑l=1.5subscriptùúÇùëô1.5\eta_{l}=1.5. The server considers the clients local work with Œ∑g=1subscriptùúÇùëî1\eta_{g}=1. We consider n‚àà{10,20,40,80}ùëõ10204080n\in\{10,20,40,80\} clients, and sample half of them at each FL optimization step. While for sake of interpretability we do not apply a decay to local and global learning rates, we note that our theory remains unchanged even in presence of a learning rate decay. In practice, for dataset with important heterogeneity, considering Œ∑g<1subscriptùúÇùëî1\eta_{g}<1 can speed-up FL with a more stable convergence.

We compare the impact of MD, Uniform, and Clustered sampling, on the convergence speed of FedAvg. With Clustered sampling, the server selects mùëöm clients from mùëöm different clusters of clients created based on the clients importance (Fraboni et al., 2021, Algorithm 1). MD sampling is a special case of Clustered sampling, where every cluster is identical.

Clients have identical importance [pi=1/nsubscriptùëùùëñ1ùëõp_{i}=1/n]. We note that Uniform sampling consistently outperforms MD sampling due to the lower covariance parameter, while the improvement between the resulting convergence speed is inversely proportional to the number of participating clients nùëõn (Figure 1a and Figure 2a-d). This result confirms the derivations of Section 3. Also, with Clustered sampling and identical client importance, every client only belongs to one cluster. Hence, Clustered sampling reduces to Uniform sampling and we retrieve identical convergence for both samplings (Figure 2a-d). This point was not raised in Fraboni et al. (2021).

Clients importance depends on the respective data ratio [pi=ni/MsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëõùëñùëÄp_{i}=n_{i}/M]. In this experimental scenario the aggregation weights for Uniform sampling do not always sum to 1, thus leading to the slow-down of FL convergence. Hence, we see in Figure 1b that MD always outperforms Uniform sampling. This experiment shows that the impact on FL convergence of the variance of the sum of the stochastic aggregation weights is more relevant than the one due to the covariance parameter Œ±ùõº\alpha. We also retrieve in Figure 2e-h that Clustered sampling always outperform MD sampling, which confirms that for two client samplings with a null variance of the sum of the stochastic aggregation weights, the one with the lowest covariance parameter Œ±ùõº\alpha converges faster. We also note that the slow-down induced by the variance is reduced when more clients do participate. This is explained by the fact that the standard deviation of the clients data ratio is reduced with larger clients participation, e.g. pi=1/10¬±0.13subscriptùëùùëñplus-or-minus1100.13p_{i}=1/10\pm 0.13 for n=10ùëõ10n=10 and pi=1/80¬±0.017subscriptùëùùëñplus-or-minus1800.017p_{i}=1/80\pm 0.017 for n=80ùëõ80n=80. We thus conclude that the difference between the effects of MD, Uniform, and Clustered sampling is mitigated with a large number of participating clients (Figure 1b and Figure2e-h).

Additional experiments on Shakespeare are provided in Appendix C. We show the influence of the amount of sampled clients mùëöm and amount of local work KùêæK on the convergence speed of MD and Uniform sampling.

Finally, additional experiments on CIFAR10 (Krizhevsky, 2009) are provided in Appendix C, where we replicate the experimental scenario previously proposed in Fraboni et al. (2021). In these applications, 100 clients are partitioned using a Dirichlet distribution which provides federated scenarios with different level of heterogeneity. For all the experimental scenarios considered, both results and conclusions are in agreement with those here derived for the Shakespeare dataset.

5 Conclusion

In this work, we highlight the asymptotic impact of client sampling on FL with Theorem 1, and shows that the convergence speed is inversely proportional to both the sum of the variance of the stochastic aggregation weights, and to their covariance parameter Œ±ùõº\alpha. Moreover, to the best of our knowledge, this work is the first one accounting for schemes where the sum of the weights is different from 1.

Thanks to our theory, we investigated MD and Uniform sampling from both theoretical and experimental standpoints. We established that when clients have approximately identical importance, i.e pi=1/nsubscriptùëùùëñ1ùëõp_{i}=1/n, Uniform outperforms MD sampling, due to the larger impact of the covariance term for the latter scheme. On the contrary, Uniform sampling is outperformed by MD sampling in more general cases, due to the slowdown induced by its stochastic aggregation weights not always summing to 1. Yet, in practical scenario with very large number of clients, MD sampling may be unpractical, and Uniform sampling could be preferred due to the more advantageous time complexity.

In this work, we also showed that our theory encompasses advanced FL sampling schemes, such as the one recently proposed in Fraboni et al. (2021), and Chen et al. (2020). Finally, while the contribution of this work is in the study of the impact of a client sampling on the global optimization objective, further extensions may focus on the analysis of the impact of clients selection method on individual users‚Äô performance, especially in presence of heterogeneity.

Appendix A Client Sampling Schemes Calculus

In this section, we calculate for MD, Uniform, Poisson, and Binomial sampling the respective aggregation weight variance Var‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St)]VarsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°\operatorname{Var}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t})\right], the covariance parameter Œ±ùõº\alpha such that Cov[œâi(St)),œâj(St)]=‚àíŒ±pipj\operatorname{Cov}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t})),\omega_{j}(S_{t})\right]=-\alpha p_{i}p_{j}, and the variance of the sum of weights Var‚Å°[‚àëi=1nœâi‚Äã(St)]Varsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°\operatorname{Var}\left[\sum_{i=1}^{n}\omega_{i}(S_{t})\right]. We also propose statistics for the parameter NùëÅN, i.e. the amount of clients the server communicates with at an iteration:

A.1 Property 1

Proposition 1.

For any client sampling, we have 0‚â§Œ±‚â§10ùõº10\leq\alpha\leq 1 and

Var‚Å°[‚àëi=1nœâi‚Äã(St)]=‚àëi=1nVar‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St)]‚àíŒ±‚Äã[1‚àí‚àëi=1npi2].Varsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõVarsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°ùõºdelimited-[]1superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ2\operatorname{Var}\left[\sum_{i=1}^{n}\omega_{i}(S_{t})\right]=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\operatorname{Var}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t})\right]-\alpha\left[1-\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}\right]. (15)
Proof.

Covariance parameter

Cov‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St),œâj‚Äã(St)]=ùîº‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St)‚Äãœâj‚Äã(St)]‚àípi‚Äãpj‚â•‚àípi‚Äãpj.CovsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùúîùëósubscriptùëÜùë°ùîºsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùúîùëósubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëósubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëó\operatorname{Cov}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t}),\omega_{j}(S_{t})\right]=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t})\omega_{j}(S_{t})\right]-p_{i}p_{j}\geq-p_{i}p_{j}. (16)

Hence, we have Œ±‚â§1.ùõº1\alpha\leq 1.

=‚àëi=1nVar‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St)]‚àíŒ±‚Äã‚àëi,j‚â†ipi‚Äãpjabsentsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõVarsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°ùõºsubscriptùëñùëóùëñsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëó\displaystyle=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\operatorname{Var}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t})\right]-\alpha\sum_{i,j\neq i}p_{i}p_{j} (18)

Var‚Å°[‚àëi=1nœâi‚Äã(St)]Varsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°\displaystyle\operatorname{Var}\left[\sum_{i=1}^{n}\omega_{i}(S_{t})\right] =‚àëi=1nVar‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St)]‚àíŒ±‚Äã[1‚àí‚àëi=1npi2],absentsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõVarsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°ùõºdelimited-[]1superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ2\displaystyle=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\operatorname{Var}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t})\right]-\alpha\left[1-\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}\right], (21)

A.2 No sampling scheme

A.3 MD sampling

We recall equation (5),

œâi‚Äã(St)=1m‚Äã‚àëk=1mùïÄ‚Äã(lk=i),subscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°1ùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùëöùïÄsubscriptùëôùëòùëñ\omega_{i}(S_{t})=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{k=1}^{m}\mathbb{I}(l_{k}=i), (23)

which gives

ùîº‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St)‚Äãœâj‚Äã(St)]ùîºsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùúîùëósubscriptùëÜùë°\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t})\omega_{j}(S_{t})\right] =1m2‚Äã‚àëk,l‚â†kùîº‚Å°[ùïÄ‚Äã(lk=i)‚ÄãùïÄ‚Äã(ll=j)]+1m2‚Äã‚àëk=1mùîº‚Å°[ùïÄ‚Äã(lk=i)‚ÄãùïÄ‚Äã(lk=j)]absent1superscriptùëö2subscriptùëòùëôùëòùîºùïÄsubscriptùëôùëòùëñùïÄsubscriptùëôùëôùëó1superscriptùëö2superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùëöùîºùïÄsubscriptùëôùëòùëñùïÄsubscriptùëôùëòùëó\displaystyle=\frac{1}{m^{2}}\sum_{k,l\neq k}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left[\mathbb{I}(l_{k}=i)\mathbb{I}(l_{l}=j)\right]+\frac{1}{m^{2}}\sum_{k=1}^{m}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left[\mathbb{I}(l_{k}=i)\mathbb{I}(l_{k}=j)\right] (24)
=1m2‚Äã‚àëk,l‚â†kpi‚Äãpj+1m2‚Äã‚àëk=1mùîº‚Å°[ùïÄ‚Äã(lk=i)‚ÄãùïÄ‚Äã(lk=j)]absent1superscriptùëö2subscriptùëòùëôùëòsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëó1superscriptùëö2superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùëöùîºùïÄsubscriptùëôùëòùëñùïÄsubscriptùëôùëòùëó\displaystyle=\frac{1}{m^{2}}\sum_{k,l\neq k}p_{i}p_{j}+\frac{1}{m^{2}}\sum_{k=1}^{m}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left[\mathbb{I}(l_{k}=i)\mathbb{I}(l_{k}=j)\right] (25)
=m‚àí1m‚Äãpi‚Äãpj+1m‚Äãùîº‚Å°[ùïÄ‚Äã(l=i)‚ÄãùïÄ‚Äã(l=j)]absentùëö1ùëösubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëó1ùëöùîºùïÄùëôùëñùïÄùëôùëó\displaystyle=\frac{m-1}{m}p_{i}p_{j}+\frac{1}{m}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left[\mathbb{I}(l=i)\mathbb{I}(l=j)\right] (26)

Variance(i=jùëñùëói=j). We get ùîº‚Å°[ùïÄ‚Äã(l=i)‚ÄãùïÄ‚Äã(l=j)]=ùîº‚Å°[ùïÄ‚Äã(l=i)]=piùîºùïÄùëôùëñùïÄùëôùëóùîºùïÄùëôùëñsubscriptùëùùëñ\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left[\mathbb{I}(l=i)\mathbb{I}(l=j)\right]=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left[\mathbb{I}(l=i)\right]=p_{i}, which gives:

Var‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St)]=‚àí1m‚Äãpi2+1m‚ÄãpiVarsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°1ùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ21ùëösubscriptùëùùëñ\operatorname{Var}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t})\right]=-\frac{1}{m}p_{i}^{2}+\frac{1}{m}p_{i} (27)

Cov‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St),œâj‚Äã(St)]=‚àí1m‚Äãpi‚Äãpj,CovsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùúîùëósubscriptùëÜùë°1ùëösubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëó\operatorname{Cov}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t}),\omega_{j}(S_{t})\right]=-\frac{1}{m}p_{i}p_{j}, (28)

and by definition we get

Œ±=1mùõº1ùëö\alpha=\frac{1}{m} (29)

Aggregation Weights Sum. Using equation (27)) and (29) with Property 1 , we get

Var‚Å°[‚àëi=1nœâi‚Äã(St)]=0.Varsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°0\operatorname{Var}\left[\sum_{i=1}^{n}\omega_{i}(S_{t})\right]=0. (30)

Amount of clients. Considering that p‚Äã(i‚ààSt)=1‚àíp‚Äã(i‚àâSt)=1‚àí(1‚àípi)mùëùùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°1ùëùùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°1superscript1subscriptùëùùëñùëöp(i\in S_{t})=1-p(i\notin S_{t})=1-(1-p_{i})^{m}, we get:

ùîº‚Å°[N]=‚àëi=1n‚Ñô‚Äã(i‚ààSt)=n‚àí‚àëi=1n(1‚àípi)m‚â§mùîºùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõ‚ÑôùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscript1subscriptùëùùëñùëöùëö\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left[N\right]=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{P}(i\in S_{t})=n-\sum_{i=1}^{n}(1-p_{i})^{m}\leq m (31)

A.4 Uniform Sampling

We recall equation (6),

œâi‚Äã(St)=ùïÄ‚Äã(i‚ààSt)‚Äãnm‚Äãpi.subscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°ùïÄùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°ùëõùëösubscriptùëùùëñ\omega_{i}(S_{t})=\mathbb{I}(i\in S_{t})\frac{n}{m}p_{i}. (32)

Variance. We first calculate the probability for a client to be sampled, i.e.

‚Ñô‚Äã(i‚ààSt)=1‚àí‚Ñô‚Äã(i‚àâSt)=1‚àín‚àí1n‚Äã‚Ä¶‚Äãn‚àímn‚àím+1=1‚àín‚àímn=mn.‚ÑôùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°1‚ÑôùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°1ùëõ1ùëõ‚Ä¶ùëõùëöùëõùëö11ùëõùëöùëõùëöùëõ\displaystyle\mathbb{P}(i\in S_{t})=1-\mathbb{P}(i\notin S_{t})=1-\frac{n-1}{n}...\frac{n-m}{n-m+1}=1-\frac{n-m}{n}=\frac{m}{n}. (33)

Using equation (33), we have

VarSt‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St)]=[nm‚Äãpi]2‚ÄãVar‚Å°[ùïÄ‚Äã(i‚ààSt)]=n2m2‚Äãmn‚Äã(1‚àímn)‚Äãpi2=(nm‚àí1)‚Äãpi2subscriptVarsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°superscriptdelimited-[]ùëõùëösubscriptùëùùëñ2VarùïÄùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°superscriptùëõ2superscriptùëö2ùëöùëõ1ùëöùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ2ùëõùëö1superscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ2\operatorname{Var}_{S_{t}}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t})\right]=\left[\frac{n}{m}p_{i}\right]^{2}\operatorname{Var}\left[\mathbb{I}(i\in S_{t})\right]=\frac{n^{2}}{m^{2}}\frac{m}{n}(1-\frac{m}{n})p_{i}^{2}=(\frac{n}{m}-1)p_{i}^{2} (34)

Covariance. We have

‚Ñô‚Äã({i,j}‚ààSt)‚ÑôùëñùëósubscriptùëÜùë°\displaystyle\mathbb{P}(\{i,j\}\in S_{t}) =‚Ñô‚Äã(i‚ààSt)+‚Ñô‚Äã(j‚ààSt)‚àí‚Ñô‚Äã(i‚à™j‚ààSt)absent‚ÑôùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°‚ÑôùëósubscriptùëÜùë°‚ÑôùëñùëósubscriptùëÜùë°\displaystyle=\mathbb{P}(i\in S_{t})+\mathbb{P}(j\in S_{t})-\mathbb{P}(i\cup j\in S_{t}) (35)
=‚Ñô‚Äã(i‚ààSt)+‚Ñô‚Äã(j‚ààSt)‚àí(1‚àí‚Ñô‚Äã({i,j}‚àâSt)),absent‚ÑôùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°‚ÑôùëósubscriptùëÜùë°1‚ÑôùëñùëósubscriptùëÜùë°\displaystyle=\mathbb{P}(i\in S_{t})+\mathbb{P}(j\in S_{t})-(1-\mathbb{P}(\{i,j\}\notin S_{t})), (36)

and

‚Ñô‚Äã({i,j}‚àâSt)=n‚àí2n‚Äã‚Ä¶‚Äãn‚àím‚àí1n‚àím+1=(n‚àím)‚Äã(n‚àím‚àí1)n‚Äã(n‚àí1).‚ÑôùëñùëósubscriptùëÜùë°ùëõ2ùëõ‚Ä¶ùëõùëö1ùëõùëö1ùëõùëöùëõùëö1ùëõùëõ1\mathbb{P}(\{i,j\}\notin S_{t})=\frac{n-2}{n}...\frac{n-m-1}{n-m+1}=\frac{(n-m)(n-m-1)}{n(n-1)}. (37)

Substituting equation (33) and (37) in equation (36) gives

‚Ñô‚Äã({i,j}‚ààSt)‚ÑôùëñùëósubscriptùëÜùë°\displaystyle\mathbb{P}(\{i,j\}\in S_{t}) =2‚Äãmn‚àí1+(n‚àím)‚Äã(n‚àím‚àí1)n‚Äã(n‚àí1)absent2ùëöùëõ1ùëõùëöùëõùëö1ùëõùëõ1\displaystyle=2\frac{m}{n}-1+\frac{(n-m)(n-m-1)}{n(n-1)} (38)

Aggregation Weights Sum. Combining equation (34) and (42) with Property 1 gives

A.5 Poisson Binomial Distribution

Clients are sampled according to a Bernoulli with a probability proportional to their importance pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i}, i.e.

œâi‚Äã(St)=1m‚Äãùîπ‚Äã(m‚Äãpi).subscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°1ùëöùîπùëösubscriptùëùùëñ\omega_{i}(S_{t})=\frac{1}{m}\mathbb{B}(mp_{i}). (44)

A.6 Binomial Distribution

Clients are sampled according to a Bernoulli with identical sampling probability, i.e.

œâi‚Äã(St)=nm‚Äãùîπ‚Äã(mn)‚Äãpi.subscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°ùëõùëöùîπùëöùëõsubscriptùëùùëñ\omega_{i}(S_{t})=\frac{n}{m}\mathbb{B}(\frac{m}{n})p_{i}. (49)

Hence, we retrieve ùîº‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St)]=nm‚Äãmn‚Äãpi=piùîºsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°ùëõùëöùëöùëõsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëñ\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t})\right]=\frac{n}{m}\frac{m}{n}p_{i}=p_{i}.

VarSt‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St)]=n2m2‚Äãmn‚Äã(1‚àímn)‚Äãpi2=n‚àímm‚Äãpi2.subscriptVarsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°superscriptùëõ2superscriptùëö2ùëöùëõ1ùëöùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ2ùëõùëöùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ2\operatorname{Var}_{S_{t}}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t})\right]=\frac{n^{2}}{m^{2}}\frac{m}{n}(1-\frac{m}{n})p_{i}^{2}=\frac{n-m}{m}p_{i}^{2}. A.7 Clustered Sampling

Clustered sampling [Fraboni et al., 2021] is a generalization of MD sampling where instead of sampling mùëöm clients from the same distributions, mùëöm clients are sampled from mùëöm different distributions {Wk}k=1msuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùëäùëòùëò1ùëö\{W_{k}\}_{k=1}^{m} each of them privileging a different subset of clients. We denote by rk,isubscriptùëüùëòùëñr_{k,i} the probability of client iùëñi to be sampled in distribution kùëòk. To satisfy Definition 1, the original work [Fraboni et al., 2021] provides the conditions:

‚àÄk‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,m},‚àëi=1nrk,i=1‚Äã¬†and¬†‚Äã‚àÄi‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,n},‚àëk=1mrk,i=m‚Äãpi.formulae-sequenceformulae-sequencefor-allùëò1‚Ä¶ùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëüùëòùëñ1¬†and¬†for-allùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùëösubscriptùëüùëòùëñùëösubscriptùëùùëñ\forall k\in\{1,...,m\},\ \sum_{i=1}^{n}r_{k,i}=1\text{ and }\forall i\in\{1,...,n\},\ \sum_{k=1}^{m}r_{k,i}=mp_{i}. (54)

The clients aggregation weights remain identical to the one of MD sampling, i.e.

œâi‚Äã(SC‚Äãl)=1m‚Äã‚àëk=1KùïÄ‚Äã(lk=i),subscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùê∂ùëô1ùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæùïÄsubscriptùëôùëòùëñ\omega_{i}(S_{Cl})=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb{I}(l_{k}=i), (55)

where ùïÄ‚Äã(lk=i)ùïÄsubscriptùëôùëòùëñ\mathbb{I}(l_{k}=i) are still independently distributed but not identically.

We have

ùîº‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St)‚Äãœâj‚Äã(St)]ùîºsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùúîùëósubscriptùëÜùë°\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t})\omega_{j}(S_{t})\right] =1m2‚Äã‚àëk,l‚â†kùîº‚Å°[ùïÄ‚Äã(lk=i)‚ÄãùïÄ‚Äã(ll=j)]+1m2‚Äã‚àëk=1mùîº‚Å°[ùïÄ‚Äã(lk=i)‚ÄãùïÄ‚Äã(lk=j)]absent1superscriptùëö2subscriptùëòùëôùëòùîºùïÄsubscriptùëôùëòùëñùïÄsubscriptùëôùëôùëó1superscriptùëö2superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùëöùîºùïÄsubscriptùëôùëòùëñùïÄsubscriptùëôùëòùëó\displaystyle=\frac{1}{m^{2}}\sum_{k,l\neq k}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left[\mathbb{I}(l_{k}=i)\mathbb{I}(l_{l}=j)\right]+\frac{1}{m^{2}}\sum_{k=1}^{m}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left[\mathbb{I}(l_{k}=i)\mathbb{I}(l_{k}=j)\right] (56)
=1m2‚Äã‚àëk,l‚â†krk,i‚Äãrl,j+1m2‚Äã‚àëk=1mùîº‚Å°[ùïÄ‚Äã(lk=i)‚ÄãùïÄ‚Äã(lk=j)]absent1superscriptùëö2subscriptùëòùëôùëòsubscriptùëüùëòùëñsubscriptùëüùëôùëó1superscriptùëö2superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùëöùîºùïÄsubscriptùëôùëòùëñùïÄsubscriptùëôùëòùëó\displaystyle=\frac{1}{m^{2}}\sum_{k,l\neq k}r_{k,i}r_{l,j}+\frac{1}{m^{2}}\sum_{k=1}^{m}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left[\mathbb{I}(l_{k}=i)\mathbb{I}(l_{k}=j)\right] (57)
=pi‚Äãpj‚àí1m2‚Äã‚àëk=1mrk,i‚Äãrk,j+1m2‚Äã‚àëk=1mùîº‚Å°[ùïÄ‚Äã(lk=i)‚ÄãùïÄ‚Äã(lk=j)],absentsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëó1superscriptùëö2superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùëösubscriptùëüùëòùëñsubscriptùëüùëòùëó1superscriptùëö2superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùëöùîºùïÄsubscriptùëôùëòùëñùïÄsubscriptùëôùëòùëó\displaystyle=p_{i}p_{j}-\frac{1}{m^{2}}\sum_{k=1}^{m}r_{k,i}r_{k,j}+\frac{1}{m^{2}}\sum_{k=1}^{m}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left[\mathbb{I}(l_{k}=i)\mathbb{I}(l_{k}=j)\right], (58)

where we retrieve equation (26) when rk,i=pisubscriptùëüùëòùëñsubscriptùëùùëñr_{k,i}=p_{i}.

Variance (i=jùëñùëói=j). We get ùîº‚Å°[ùïÄ‚Äã(lk=i)‚ÄãùïÄ‚Äã(lk=j)]=ùîº‚Å°[ùïÄ‚Äã(lk=i)]=rk,iùîºùïÄsubscriptùëôùëòùëñùïÄsubscriptùëôùëòùëóùîºùïÄsubscriptùëôùëòùëñsubscriptùëüùëòùëñ\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left[\mathbb{I}(l_{k}=i)\mathbb{I}(l_{k}=j)\right]=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left[\mathbb{I}(l_{k}=i)\right]=r_{k,i}, which gives:

Var‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(SC‚Äãl)]=1m‚Äãpi‚àí1m2‚Äã‚àëk=1mrk,i2‚â§Var‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(SM‚ÄãD)],VarsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùê∂ùëô1ùëösubscriptùëùùëñ1superscriptùëö2superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëüùëòùëñ2VarsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùëÄùê∑\operatorname{Var}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{Cl})\right]=\frac{1}{m}p_{i}-\frac{1}{m^{2}}\sum_{k=1}^{m}r_{k,i}^{2}\leq\operatorname{Var}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{MD})\right], (59)

where the inequality comes from using the Cauchy-Schwartz inequality with equality if and only if all the mùëöm distributions are identical, i.e. rk,i=pisubscriptùëüùëòùëñsubscriptùëùùëñr_{k,i}=p_{i}.

Cov‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(SC‚Äãl),œâj‚Äã(SC‚Äãl)]=‚àí1m2‚Äã‚àëk=1mrk,i‚Äãrk,j‚â§Cov‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(SM‚ÄãD),œâj‚Äã(SM‚ÄãD)],CovsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùê∂ùëôsubscriptùúîùëósubscriptùëÜùê∂ùëô1superscriptùëö2superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùëösubscriptùëüùëòùëñsubscriptùëüùëòùëóCovsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùëÄùê∑subscriptùúîùëósubscriptùëÜùëÄùê∑\operatorname{Cov}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{Cl}),\omega_{j}(S_{Cl})\right]=-\frac{1}{m^{2}}\sum_{k=1}^{m}r_{k,i}r_{k,j}\leq\operatorname{Cov}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{MD}),\omega_{j}(S_{MD})\right], (60)

where the inequality comes from using the Cauchy-Schwartz inequality with equality if and only if all the mùëöm distributions are identical, i.e. rk,i=pisubscriptùëüùëòùëñsubscriptùëùùëñr_{k,i}=p_{i}.

A.8 Optimal Sampling

With optimal sampling [Chen et al., 2020], clients are sampled according to a Bernoulli distribution with probability qisubscriptùëûùëñq_{i}, i.e.

œâi‚Äã(St)=piqi‚Äãùîπ‚Äã(qi).subscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëûùëñùîπsubscriptùëûùëñ\omega_{i}(S_{t})=\frac{p_{i}}{q_{i}}\mathbb{B}(q_{i}). (62)

Hence, we retrieve ùîº‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St)]=piqi‚Äãqi=piùîºsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëûùëñsubscriptùëûùëñsubscriptùëùùëñ\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t})\right]=\frac{p_{i}}{q_{i}}q_{i}=p_{i}.

Variance.

VarSt‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St)]=1‚àíqiqi‚Äãpi2.subscriptVarsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°1subscriptùëûùëñsubscriptùëûùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ2\operatorname{Var}_{S_{t}}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t})\right]=\frac{1-q_{i}}{q_{i}}p_{i}^{2}. (63)

Covariance. Due to the independence of each stochastic weight, we have:

Cov‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St),œâj‚Äã(St)]=0.CovsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùúîùëósubscriptùëÜùë°0\operatorname{Cov}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t}),\omega_{j}(S_{t})\right]=0. (64)

Aggregation Weights Sum. Using Property 1 gives

Var‚Å°[‚àëi=1nœâi‚Äã(St)]=‚àëi=1n1‚àíqiqi‚Äãpi2.Varsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõ1subscriptùëûùëñsubscriptùëûùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ2\operatorname{Var}\left[\sum_{i=1}^{n}\omega_{i}(S_{t})\right]=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{1-q_{i}}{q_{i}}p_{i}^{2}. (65)

Amount of Clients.

ùîº‚Å°[N]=‚àëi=1nqi‚Äã¬†and¬†‚ÄãVar‚Å°[N]=‚àëi=1nqi‚Äã(1‚àíqi).ùîºùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëûùëñ¬†and¬†VarùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëûùëñ1subscriptùëûùëñ\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left[N\right]=\sum_{i=1}^{n}q_{i}\text{ and }\operatorname{Var}\left[N\right]=\sum_{i=1}^{n}q_{i}(1-q_{i}). (66)

Appendix B FL Convergence

In Table 2, we provide the definition of the different notations used in this work. We also propose in Algorithm 1 the pseudo-code for FedAvg with aggregation scheme (3). Our work is based on the one of Wang et al. [2020a]. We use the developed theoretical framework they proposed to prove Theorem 1. The focus of our work (and Theorem 1) is on FedAvg. Yet, the proof developed in this section, similarly to the one of Wang et al. [2020a], expresses aisubscriptùëéùëña_{i} in such a way they can account for a wide-range of regularization method on FedAvg, or optimizers different from Vanilla SGD. This proof can easily be extended to account for different amount of local work from the clients [Wang et al., 2020a].

Before developing the proof of Theorem 1 in Section B.5, we introduce the notation we use in Section B.1, some useful lemmas in Section B.2 and Theorem 2 generalizing Theorem 1 in Section B.3.

B.2 Useful Lemmas

Lemma 1.

Let us consider nùëõn vectors ùê±i,‚Ä¶,ùê±nsubscriptùê±ùëñ‚Ä¶subscriptùê±ùëõ{\bm{x}}_{i},...,{\bm{x}}_{n} and a client sampling satisfying ùîºSt‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St)]=pisubscriptùîºsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùëùùëñ\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}_{S_{t}}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t})\right]=p_{i} and Cov‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St),œâj‚Äã(St)]=‚àíŒ±‚Äãpi‚ÄãpjCovsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùúîùëósubscriptùëÜùë°ùõºsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëó\operatorname{Cov}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t}),\omega_{j}(S_{t})\right]=-\alpha p_{i}p_{j}. We have:

ùîºSt‚Å°[‚à•‚àëi=1nœâi‚Äã(St)‚Äãùíôi‚à•2]=‚àëi=1nŒ≥i‚Äã‚à•ùíôi‚à•2+(1‚àíŒ±)‚Äã‚à•‚àëi=1npi‚Äãùíôi‚à•2,subscriptùîºsubscriptùëÜùë°superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùíôùëñ2superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùõæùëñsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùíôùëñ21ùõºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùíôùëñ2\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}_{S_{t}}\left[\left\lVert\sum_{i=1}^{n}\omega_{i}(S_{t}){\bm{x}}_{i}\right\rVert^{2}\right]=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\gamma_{i}\left\lVert{\bm{x}}_{i}\right\rVert^{2}+(1-\alpha)\left\lVert\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}{\bm{x}}_{i}\right\rVert^{2}, (70)

where Œ≥i=VarSt‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St)]+Œ±‚Äãpi2subscriptùõæùëñsubscriptVarsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°ùõºsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ2\gamma_{i}=\operatorname{Var}_{S_{t}}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t})\right]+\alpha p_{i}^{2}.

Proof.
ùîºSt‚Å°[‚à•‚àëi=1nœâi‚Äã(St)‚Äãùíôi‚à•2]subscriptùîºsubscriptùëÜùë°superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùíôùëñ2\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}_{S_{t}}\left[\left\lVert\sum_{i=1}^{n}\omega_{i}(S_{t}){\bm{x}}_{i}\right\rVert^{2}\right] =‚àëi=1nùîºSt‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St)2]‚Äã‚à•ùíôi‚à•2+‚àëi=1n‚àëj=1j‚â†inùîºSt‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St)‚Äãœâj‚Äã(St)]‚Äã‚ü®ùíôi,ùíôj‚ü©.absentsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùîºsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùúîùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùë°2superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùíôùëñ2superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëóùëñùëõsubscriptùîºsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùúîùëósubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùíôùëñsubscriptùíôùëó\displaystyle=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}_{S_{t}}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t})^{2}\right]\left\lVert{\bm{x}}_{i}\right\rVert^{2}+\sum_{i=1}^{n}\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}j=1\\ j\neq i\end{subarray}}^{n}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}_{S_{t}}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t})\omega_{j}(S_{t})\right]\langle{\bm{x}}_{i},{\bm{x}}_{j}\rangle. (71)

In addition, we have:

ùîºSt‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St)‚Äãœâj‚Äã(St)]=Cov‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St),œâj‚Äã(St)]+pi‚Äãpj=(‚àíŒ±+1)‚Äãpi‚Äãpj,subscriptùîºsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùúîùëósubscriptùëÜùë°CovsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùúîùëósubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëóùõº1subscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëó\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}_{S_{t}}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t})\omega_{j}(S_{t})\right]=\operatorname{Cov}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t}),\omega_{j}(S_{t})\right]+p_{i}p_{j}=(-\alpha+1)p_{i}p_{j}, (72)

where the last equality comes from the assumption on the client sampling covariance.

We also have:

‚àëi=1n‚àëj=1j‚â†in‚ü®pi‚Äãùíôi,pj‚Äãùíôj‚ü©=‚à•‚àëi=1npi‚Äãùíôi‚à•2‚àí‚àëi=1npi2‚Äã‚à•ùíôi‚à•2,superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëóùëñùëõsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùíôùëñsubscriptùëùùëósubscriptùíôùëósuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùíôùëñ2superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ2superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùíôùëñ2\sum_{i=1}^{n}\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}j=1\\ j\neq i\end{subarray}}^{n}\langle p_{i}{\bm{x}}_{i},p_{j}{\bm{x}}_{j}\rangle=\left\lVert\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}{\bm{x}}_{i}\right\rVert^{2}-\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}\left\lVert{\bm{x}}_{i}\right\rVert^{2}, (73)

Substituting equation (72) and equation (73) in equation (71) gives:

ùîºSt‚Å°[‚à•‚àëi=1nœâi‚Äã(St)‚Äãùíôi‚à•2]=‚àëi=1n[ùîºSt‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St)2]‚àí(‚àíŒ±+1)‚Äãpi2]‚Äã‚à•ùíôi‚à•2+(‚àíŒ±+1)‚Äã‚à•‚àëi=1npi‚Äãùíôi‚à•2,subscriptùîºsubscriptùëÜùë°superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùíôùëñ2superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõdelimited-[]subscriptùîºsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùúîùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùë°2ùõº1superscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ2superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùíôùëñ2ùõº1superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùíôùëñ2\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}_{S_{t}}\left[\left\lVert\sum_{i=1}^{n}\omega_{i}(S_{t}){\bm{x}}_{i}\right\rVert^{2}\right]=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left[\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}_{S_{t}}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t})^{2}\right]-(-\alpha+1)p_{i}^{2}\right]\left\lVert{\bm{x}}_{i}\right\rVert^{2}+(-\alpha+1)\left\lVert\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}{\bm{x}}_{i}\right\rVert^{2}, (74)

Considering that we have ùîºSt‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St)2]=Var‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St)]+pi2subscriptùîºsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùúîùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùë°2VarsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°superscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ2\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}_{S_{t}}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t})^{2}\right]=\operatorname{Var}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t})\right]+p_{i}^{2}, we have :

ùîºSt‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St)2]+(Œ±‚àí1)‚Äãpi2=VarSt‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St)]+Œ±‚Äãpi2,subscriptùîºsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùúîùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùë°2ùõº1superscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ2subscriptVarsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°ùõºsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ2\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}_{S_{t}}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t})^{2}\right]+(\alpha-1)p_{i}^{2}=\operatorname{Var}_{S_{t}}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t})\right]+\alpha p_{i}^{2}, (75)

Substituting equation (75) in equation (74) completes the proof.

Lemma 2 (equation (87) in Wang et al. [2020a]).

Under Assumptions 2 to 4, we can prove

Proof.

The proof is in Section C.5 of Wang et al. [2020a].

Using Assumption 3 in equation (87) and R‚Ä≤<1superscriptùëÖ‚Ä≤1R^{\prime}<1 completes the proof.

Theorem 2.

The following inequality holds:

1T‚Äã‚àët=0T‚àí1ùîº‚Å°[‚à•‚àá‚Ñí~‚Äã(ùúΩt)‚à•2]1ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùë°0ùëá1ùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àá~‚ÑísuperscriptùúΩùë°2\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left[\left\lVert\nabla\tilde{\mathcal{L}}({\bm{\theta}}^{t})\right\rVert^{2}\right] ‚â§ùí™‚Äã(1(1‚àíŒ©)‚ÄãŒ∑~‚Äã(‚àëi=1npi‚Äãai)‚ÄãT)+ùí™‚Äã(Œ∑~‚Äã1m‚ÄãA‚Ä≤‚ÄãœÉ2)+ùí™‚Äã(Œ∑l2‚ÄãB‚Ä≤‚ÄãœÉ2)absentùí™11Œ©~ùúÇsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëéùëñùëáùí™~ùúÇ1ùëösuperscriptùê¥‚Ä≤superscriptùúé2ùí™superscriptsubscriptùúÇùëô2superscriptùêµ‚Ä≤superscriptùúé2\displaystyle\leq\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{(1-\Omega)\tilde{\eta}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}a_{i}\right)T})+\mathcal{O}(\tilde{\eta}\frac{1}{m}A^{\prime}\sigma^{2})+\mathcal{O}(\eta_{l}^{2}B^{\prime}\sigma^{2})

B.6 Application to Clustered Sampling

Instead of Lemma 1 which requires Cov‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St),œâj‚Äã(St)]=‚àíŒ±‚Äãpi‚ÄãpjCovsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùúîùëósubscriptùëÜùë°ùõºsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëó\operatorname{Cov}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t}),\omega_{j}(S_{t})\right]=-\alpha p_{i}p_{j}, we propose the following Lemma for Clustered sampling expressed in function of MD sampling covariance parameter Œ±M‚ÄãDsubscriptùõºùëÄùê∑\alpha_{MD} showing that a sufficient condition for MD sampling to perform as well as Clustered sampling is that all ùíôisubscriptùíôùëñ{\bm{x}}_{i} are identical, or that all the distributions are identical, i.e. rk,i=pisubscriptùëüùëòùëñsubscriptùëùùëñr_{k,i}=p_{i}.

(122)

Using the expression of clustered sampling variance for the first term (equation (60)), and using Jensen‚Äôs inequality on the third term completes the proof. Jensen‚Äôs inequality is an equality if and only if ‚àëi=1nrk,i‚Äãùíôi=‚àëj=1nrk,j‚Äãùíôjsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëüùëòùëñsubscriptùíôùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëõsubscriptùëüùëòùëósubscriptùíôùëó\sum_{i=1}^{n}r_{k,i}{\bm{x}}_{i}=\sum_{j=1}^{n}r_{k,j}{\bm{x}}_{j}.

‚àé

We adapt Theorem 1 to Clustered sampling. Fraboni et al. [2021] prove the convergence of FL with clustered sampling by giving identical convergence guarantees to the one of FL with MD sampling. As a result, their convergence bound does not depend of the clients selection probability in the different clusters rk,isubscriptùëüùëòùëñr_{k,i}. The authors‚Äô claim was that reducing the variance of the aggregation weights provides faster FL convergence, albeit only providing experimental proofs was provided to support this statement. Corollary 2 here proposed extends the theory of Fraboni et al. [2021] by theoretically demonstrating the influence of clustered sampling on the convergence rate. For easing the notation, Corollary 2 is adapted to FedAvg but can easily be extended to account for any local ùíÇisubscriptùíÇùëñ{\bm{a}}_{i} using the proof of Theorem 2 in Section B.3.

Corollary 2.

Even with no Œ±ùõº\alpha such that Cov‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(St),œâj‚Äã(St)]=‚àíŒ±‚Äãpi‚ÄãpjCovsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùúîùëósubscriptùëÜùë°ùõºsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëó\operatorname{Cov}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{t}),\omega_{j}(S_{t})\right]=-\alpha p_{i}p_{j}, the bound of Theorem 1 still holds with BùêµB, Cùê∂C, and Dùê∑D defined as in Section B.3 and

A=m‚Äã[1m‚àí1m2‚Äã‚àëi=1n‚àëk=1mrk,i2+‚àëi=1npi2],E=1m‚Äã(K‚àí1),¬†and¬†‚ÄãF=1m‚ÄãK,formulae-sequenceùê¥ùëödelimited-[]1ùëö1superscriptùëö2superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëüùëòùëñ2superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ2formulae-sequenceùê∏1ùëöùêæ1¬†and¬†ùêπ1ùëöùêæA=m\left[\frac{1}{m}-\frac{1}{m^{2}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\sum_{k=1}^{m}r_{k,i}^{2}+\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}\right],\ E=\frac{1}{m}(K-1),\text{ and }F=\frac{1}{m}K, (123)

where Eùê∏E and FùêπF are identical to the one for MD sampling and Aùê¥A is smaller than the one for Clustered sampling.

Proof.

The covariance property required for Theorem 2 is only used for Lemma 1. In the proof of Theorem 2, Lemma 1 is only used in equation (96). We can instead use Lemma 4 and keep the rest of the proof as it is in Section B.3. Therefore, the bound of Theorem 2 remains unchanged for clustered sampling where Eùê∏E and FùêπF use the aggregation weight statistics of MD sampling instead of clustered sampling. Statistics for MD sampling can be found in Section A.3 and give

Var‚Å°[‚àëi=1nœâi‚Äã(SM‚ÄãD)]=0‚Äã¬†and¬†‚ÄãŒ±M‚ÄãD=1m,Varsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùëÄùê∑0¬†and¬†subscriptùõºùëÄùê∑1ùëö\operatorname{Var}\left[\sum_{i=1}^{n}\omega_{i}(S_{MD})\right]=0\text{ and }\alpha_{MD}=\frac{1}{m}, (124)

while the ones of clustered sampling in Section A.7 give

B.7 Proof of Corollary 1

Proof.

Combining equation (27) with equation (34) gives

Œ£M‚ÄãD‚àíŒ£U=[‚àí1m‚Äã‚àëi=1npi2+1m]‚àí(nm‚àí1)‚Äã‚àëi=1npi2=‚àí1m‚Äã[(n‚àím+1)‚Äã‚àëi=1npi2‚àí1].subscriptŒ£ùëÄùê∑subscriptŒ£ùëàdelimited-[]1ùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ21ùëöùëõùëö1superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ21ùëödelimited-[]ùëõùëö1superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ21\displaystyle\Sigma_{MD}-\Sigma_{U}=\left[-\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}+\frac{1}{m}\right]-\left(\frac{n}{m}-1\right)\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}=-\frac{1}{m}\left[(n-m+1)\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}-1\right]. (126)

Therefore, we have

Œ£M‚ÄãD‚â§Œ£U‚áî‚àëi=1npi2‚â§1n‚àím+1.‚áîsubscriptŒ£ùëÄùê∑subscriptŒ£ùëàsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ21ùëõùëö1\Sigma_{MD}\leq\Sigma_{U}\Leftrightarrow\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}\leq\frac{1}{n-m+1}. (127)

Combining equation (29), (30), (42), and (43) gives

Œ≥M‚ÄãD‚àíŒ≥U=‚àëi=1nVar‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(SM‚ÄãD)]+Œ±M‚ÄãD‚Äã‚àëi=1npi2‚àí(‚àëi=1nVar‚Å°[œâi‚Äã(SU)]+Œ±U‚Äã‚àëi=1npi2)=1m‚àín‚àímm‚Äã(n‚àí1)‚Äãn‚Äã‚àëi=1npi2.subscriptùõæùëÄùê∑subscriptùõæùëàsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõVarsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùëÄùê∑subscriptùõºùëÄùê∑superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ2superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõVarsubscriptùúîùëñsubscriptùëÜùëàsubscriptùõºùëàsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ21ùëöùëõùëöùëöùëõ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ2\displaystyle\gamma_{MD}-\gamma_{U}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\operatorname{Var}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{MD})\right]+\alpha_{MD}\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}-\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\operatorname{Var}\left[\omega_{i}(S_{U})\right]+\alpha_{U}\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}\right)=\frac{1}{m}-\frac{n-m}{m(n-1)}n\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}. (128)

Therefore, we have

Œ≥M‚ÄãD‚â§Œ≥U‚áî‚àëi=1npi2‚â§1n‚àím‚Äãn‚àí1n.‚áîsubscriptùõæùëÄùê∑subscriptùõæùëàsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ21ùëõùëöùëõ1ùëõ\gamma_{MD}\leq\gamma_{U}\Leftrightarrow\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{2}\leq\frac{1}{n-m}\frac{n-1}{n}. (129)

Noting that

1n‚àím+1‚àí1n‚àím‚Äãn‚àí1n=‚àím+1n‚Äã(n‚àím)‚Äã(n‚àím+1)‚â§0,1ùëõùëö11ùëõùëöùëõ1ùëõùëö1ùëõùëõùëöùëõùëö10\frac{1}{n-m+1}-\frac{1}{n-m}\frac{n-1}{n}=\frac{-m+1}{n(n-m)(n-m+1)}\leq 0, (130)

completes the proof.

Appendix C Additional experiments

C.1 Shakespeare dataset

The client local learning rate Œ∑lsubscriptùúÇùëô\eta_{l} is selected in {0.1, 0.5, 1., 1.5, 2., 2.5} minimizing FedAvg with full participation, and n=80ùëõ80n=80 training loss at the end of the learning process.

C.2 CIFAR10 dataset

We consider the experimental scenario used to prove the experimental correctness of clustered sampling in [Fraboni et al., 2021] on CIFAR10 [Krizhevsky, 2009]. The dataset is partitioned in n=100ùëõ100n=100 clients using a Dirichlet distribution with parameter Œ±=0.1ùõº0.1\alpha=0.1 as proposed in Harry Hsu et al. [2019]. 10, 30, 30, 20 and 10 clients have respectively 100, 250, 500, 750, and 1000 training samples, and testing samples amounting to a fifth of their training size. The client local learning rate Œ∑lsubscriptùúÇùëô\eta_{l} is selected in {0.01, 0.02, 0.05, 0.1}.
